  11. Testing your code
  12. Checkpoint 2

Testing your code using a simple main method

Write a class named AtomTest. Inside its main method, create an instance of a Uranium-238 atom (92 protons, 146 neutrons, 92 electrons). Print the values you get from the accessor methods and make sure they are correct. Then call the decay() method and check the results again.

Running a SpecChecker

Download the SpecChecker for the Atom class. Import it into your project and run it as in Lab 1. Refer to the SpecChecker HOWTO to remember how to do this.

This SpecChecker will, like the ones for miniassignments, perform a few basic functional tests of your Atom class. When all is working correctly, you should see the message "You received 13/13 points. 11 out of 11 tests pass." Try putting some errors in your code, for example, subtract where you should be adding. See whether the error is detected by the tests.

When you are satisfied with the results, go ahead and let the SpecChecker create a zip file for you and submit it on Blackboard ("Lab 2 practice submission").

After submitting it, go to your submission history page on Blackboard and make sure the file you uploaded is there. Then check its contents as described in the Assignment Submission HOWTO.

(Recall from lab 1 that the document "Assignment Submission HOWTO" describes in detail how to submit an assignment to Blackboard and how to check that the submission was correct.)
